title: 103_hr4917
content: The Act may be cited as the "Electronic Freedom of Information Improvement Act of 1994". The Congress finds that the purpose of the Freedom of Information Act is to make agency information available for public inspection, leading to the disclosure of government operations, waste, fraud, and abuse. The Freedom of Information Act aims to ensure public access to agency records, improve transparency, and promote democracy by disclosing government operations and preventing abuse. Government agencies are encouraged to use new technology to enhance public access to valuable information. SEC. 3 amends Section 552(a)(1) of title 5, United States Code to include electronic means for public information availability. It also requires agencies to provide a list of statutes used to withhold information. SEC. 4 mandates materials to be available in electronic format. Section 552(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code is amended to include provisions for electronic availability of agency records and the requirement for an index of major information systems containing agency records. The amendment includes provisions for electronic availability of agency records, a requirement for an index of major information systems, and guidelines for indicating deletions in records. SEC. 5. LIST OF RECORDS MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC AND HONORING FORMAT REQUESTS. Section 552(a)(3) of title 5, United States Code is amended to include provisions for making records available to the public for inspection and copying. The amended Section 552(a)(3) of title 5, United States Code requires agencies to provide records for inspection and copying as requested by any person, in any form or format maintained by the agency, including electronic formats. Agencies must make reasonable efforts to fulfill requests even if the records are not typically maintained in that form. SEC. 6. DELAYS. The text discusses the amendment of fees and payment of expenses related to document requests under Section 552(a)(4) of title 5, United States Code. One-half of the fees collected will be credited to the agency for compliance costs, while the remaining fees will go to the Treasury. Additionally, the court may address the expenses of the person making a request. The amendment allows the court to assess out-of-pocket expenses and attorney fees against the United States for non-compliance with time limits in document requests. Agencies must justify delays under specific circumstances. Section 552(a)(6)(A)(i) is amended to extend the time limit from "ten days" to "twenty days" for document requests. Section 552(a)(6)(C) clarifies that "exceptional circumstances" do not include delays from predictable workloads or agency backlogs. Additionally, notification of denial must include names and titles of those responsible and the number of denied records. Each agency must adopt a first-in, first-out (FIFO) processing policy for requests, with separate tracks for simple and complex requests. Simple requests should be decided within 10 days, while complex requests may take longer. This multitrack system does not override due process claims. Each agency must adopt a first-in, first-out (FIFO) processing policy for requests, with separate tracks for simple and complex requests. A multitrack system shall not negate a claim of due diligence if FIFO processing is maintained within each track. Agencies must determine within 5 days whether to comply with expedited access requests, notifying the requester of the decision within 1 day. Requests for expedited access to records must be processed promptly by the agency. If expedited access is denied or not decided within 5 days, the requester must exhaust administrative remedies. Appeals can be made to the head of the agency within specific timeframes. The agency must promptly process requests for expedited access to records. If denied or not decided within 5 days, the requester must exhaust administrative remedies. Appeals can be made to the agency head within specific timeframes. If the agency denies expedited access, a court may require the agency to show cause for denial, limited to the agency's record. The burden of demonstrating a compelling need for expedited access can be met by certifying under penalty of perjury that failure to obtain the records would threaten an individual's life or safety. The agency must promptly process requests for expedited access to records, with appeals available if denied. A compelling need for expedited access can be demonstrated by certifying under penalty of perjury that failure to obtain the records would threaten an individual's life or safety. SEC. 7 amends Section 552(b) of title 5, US Code to require indicating deletions on released records. SEC. 8 provides definitions. Section 552(f) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to define terms such as 'agency', 'record', and 'search' for the purpose of conducting reviews of agency records in response to requests. The amendment to Section 552(f) of title 5, United States Code, defines terms for reviewing agency records in response to requests, including those responsive to subsection (a)(3)(A).
